[doubling](doubling.html) has special orthographic provenance:

A grammatical form between singular and [plural](Plural),  
the dual is preseved in some [european](PIE) languages.  
In Egyptian it is written as ğ“® ğ“­ ğ“‡Œ ğ“‡‹ğ“‡‹, read as ee,ei,ii,j  
In [Proto-Indo-European](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_nominals) it has forms of -hâ‚e -ihâ‚ -oyhâ‚  
In Arabic, bahr**ayn** is the [dual](Dual) form of bahr ("sea") Bachâ‡¨Bahrainâ‡¨BÃ¤che Baqua [Bug](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bug_River)  
The late reading of ğ“­ ğ“‡Œ [ğ“‡‹](ğ“‡‹)ğ“‡‹ as **ay** is consistent with the Arabic bahrayn  

There is a tendency for the loss of the dual as a productive form in later Egyptian.  

Provocative reading:  suffix [ğ“®](ğ“®) as *di* *ti* or bi [ğ“­](ğ“­) ğ“‡Œ [ğ“‡‹](ğ“‡‹)ğ“‡‹  

[ğ“ƒ€](ğ“ƒ€) Ein Bein (1 foot 1 podOn 1 podUs) on/as/us=1 eins  
[ğ“‚¾](ğ“‚¾)[ğ“ƒ€](ğ“ƒ€) Beide Beine (2 poDi/feet) di=2
